bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, July 24, 1942

div1.p: Hench discusses the controversy between Kissinger and Moran, which centers on who first volunteered for the yellow fever experiments. He feels the truth will never be known, and advises Wood not to reopen the matter.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, July 24, 1942
div1.p:
After some delay my commission (lieutenant colonel) and final orders came
through yesterday. I leave on the seventh for a month or two of preliminary training
at Fort Custer near Battle Creek and then go to be chief of the medical service at
the Station Hospital, Camp Carson, near Colorado Springs. I think you had better
address me here as I don't know my exact post office address in these camps.

I am delighted to know that the Junior Literary Guild is sponsoring your book.
I know you hate the delay but the money will be very welcome.

I am sorry that you have had the Kissinger-Moran controversy reopened for you.
I can't begin to go into this controversy within the confines of a letter and wish
that we could chat over it and I could tell you a lot of personal and confidential
things that I have uncovered about it. Very briefly the situation is this. Each of
these men insisted vehemently to me that he was the first and that the other volunteered
a day or so later. Kissinger is a sweet old thing but a rather ignorant, uneducated
farmer who because of illness and destitute circumstances had to go into the “hero
business” as his only means of support. In a simple, childlike way he has enjoyed it
but he is thoroughly honest within the limits of his memory and a fine character. Hav-
ing told and retold his story ten thousand times and having lived on his past experience
you can see how his story might well become colored. I visited his home and indeed
had him up here visiting us and took his story down in shorthand. It is riddled with
errors and while it was slightly helpful, his story has been the least helpful of all
the survivors.

Moran is a much stronger, abler character, completely and utterly honest
I am sure but not adverse on occasion to telling a white lie when his code of an Irish
gentleman seems to demand it. My original purpose in 1937 and 1938 was to get the
story of these two men and publish it. The snag here was that on the main issue--the
most dramatic point of the story--that of the volunteering--they entirely disagreed.

A few months ago I uncovered a letter written by Moran several years ago to Dr.
Peabody of New York who, as you know, was largely responsible for the medals and in this
letter Moran specifically stated that he had volunteered first, talked the matter over
that night with Kissinger and that Kissinger either the next day or the following day had
volunteered. I already had a different story from Moran himself: that Moran had decided
to volunteer, had talked most of the night with Kissinger and that they had both gone in
the next day and volunteered. The last time I visited Havana, toward the end of my
visit, I sprang that discrepancy on Moran, actually showing him the two versions in
his own handwriting. After an embarrassing long period of silence, he turned to me
and said, “Dr. Hench, now you know that we are all liars--all of us connected with the
yellow fever experiments. Why don't you just quit the whole thing?” He seemed much
distressed that I had caught him in this discrepancy and it took some talking and
diplomacy on my part to make him open up and explain it. I cannot give it to you in
detail but in brief this is the explanation: that he in fact did volunteer first,
that he was quite disappointed when Reed inoculated Kissinger first as he (Moran) had
volunteered first, as he had expected that “honor”; that later, when Kean presented
Kissinger with a watch and a citation he (Moran) an ex-army man not in uniform was

only invited to stand on the sidelines and received no watch nor citation. All of
these had hurt him--to think that because he was not in uniform, his enlistment
having just ended, that he was treated differently from one still in uniform. It
hurt him to think that Reed had allowed the distinction to be made, but later (as
he explains his motives), in order to restore his loyalty to Reed and not expose
this slight flaw in Reed's character he (Moran) changed his story to agree with that
of Kissinger (in order to smooth everything out). He wants to stick to the latter
story that they enlisted together even though he insists it is not true.

Nobody really knows who enlisted first. I don't even think Kissinger himself
knows. General Kean is under the impression that Moran volunteered first but that
Kissinger was bitten first. I don't have my records with me but isn't it right that
both were bitten on the same day but Kissinger got sick first? General Truby told
me that he thought that Kissinger volunteered first. Why not avoid this controversy?
It is of no interest to school children and unless you give them equal preference
either one or the other of these two good and worthy characters will be hurt. They
will be much less hurt and much more satisfied if you and I and those to follow
after make the compromise and say that they volunteered essentially together.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
